comments.commentBody: The good professor at Univ of Miami needs to talk with Senator Inhoffe to get his mind straight.

I like to attend science lectures. There are a lot of them that are usually free to attend in major cities. Whenever the topic is anything close to global warming, I always ask this question during the Q & A after the talk.

"Dr. Soandso, is it possible that it's simply too late to do anything that will bring us back from certain destruction now?"

This often causes the lecturer to pause for a long time before answering. The answer is usually some form of, "Yes, but I refuse to allow myself to think about that."

About four years ago, I listened to Dr. Harold R. Wanless, chair of geological sciences at the University of Miami, explain how his city is pretty much doomed to disappear with rising sea level that will have bad effects like ruining the local water supply before most of the city has to be abandoned.  Levees won't work due to the porous limestone rock underlying the area.  When he was asked about the ruins, Wanless replied that abandoned buildings, even well-built concrete ones, fall apart rapidly.  So much for the vision of towers of a sunken Manhattan in Steven Spielberg's AI movie.

Douglas: Let's just hope that the deniers follow your advice: don't panic, but don't deny reality, either. I think some people find it hard to believe that puny little human actions can have an effect on such large systems as weather, but whether or not climate change is human caused, human actions can indeed mitigate it.

Janice,

You wrote, "I doubt that there is anybody who really doesn't believe in climate change. I doubt that there is anybody who really doesn't believe in climate change."

You have a MUCH higher opinion of human intellect than I do.

The situation reminds me of the early days of the recycling "movement."  People mostly said "Oh, recycling is wonderful.  I'm for it. Absolutely!  Just so long as I don't have to incur any cost at all or change my behaviour in any way ."

I doubt that there is anybody who really doesn't believe in climate change. We can see it happening. I have relatives living up and down the coast from Alaska to Southren Californa. All of them are concerned about the weird weather we've been having lately.
I think that what the people who say climate change is hoax really mean is "I can see it all right, but I don't want to spend any money trying to solve the problem."
Or, as Mark Twain said, "Everybody complains about the weather, but nobody does anything about it."
I imagine that sounded a lot fuinnier then.
If one is temperamental and insecure maybe not.
Federer did, for a while; I think he was the last one.
Is it possible to win and/or be competitive without a coach?
But he didn't.  He's just not the best.  Sampras was.
So Fed had a new gameplan against Rafa? Worked for less than half the match before Rafa figured it out and counter attacked. Rafa is simply the better player no matter what Roger's game plan is.

Roger (and his fans) should be thrilled with his play tonight, especially in light of his recent matches against Rafa.  Let's see where Rafa and Djokovic are when they are 32.    The one thing thats frustrating is seeing Federer *finally* use the right gameplan against Rafa. Aggressive returns as often as possible, and attack the Rafa backhand as often as possible - its frustrating that it took him that long to realize that's the right play.  If he had done that earlier in his career, he'd have won the '08 Wimbledon and '09 Australian.

The US is not paying the Egyptian army for altruistic reasons. It is a simple bribe to keep them on Israel's side and if a side-effect is repression of generations of Egyptians, stagnation of the country, etc., so be it. If the US was such a champion of democracy, please point me to one piece of evidence where it has pushed for democracy in Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Kuwait, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Azerbaijan, Kyrgistan, etc. These countries are being run by repressive kings and dictators. +One word: oil. The country it has occupied for the last 12 years - Afghanistan - has had the same stooge all this time. Why?  Americans should free themselves from the notion that their government fights for democracy abroad - it fights for the "interests" of American people. When ever there is a contest between "values" and "interests", the latter triumphs. And this was fine post WW2, and in the cold war years. But the world has caught on now to the charade.

I'm in my 7th decade of life and I think for about five of those, I've been saying something like, "I think our system is the best.  If it is indeed the best, the rest of the world will eventually figure that out on their own. Give them time.  History is long.  If it turns out not to be the best system for everyone after all, nothing we do to try to impose it on the rest of the world will work any more than any other country imposing their system on us would work simply because their people happen to think it is best." Considering the political mess our country is in right now, I am not sure we should be holding our partially dysfunctional govt up as an example to anyone, but even were it functioning smoothly, hammering people over the head with the idea of how wonderful we think we are is definitely not a way to win friends and influence people around the world any more than hearing how wonderful a know-it-all acquaintance is from the mouth of the acquaintance him- or herself is likely to make her/him the most popular person in the group.  In what culture does aggressively and self-righteously tooting one's own horn succeed in making friends and gaining admiration?

Interesting comments, as always Rima.  But the point Kupchan's article isn't to get us to stop "expectiing democracy", it is to get us, as Americans, to acquiesce in continuing to bankrolling the Egyptian military whom we pay to police the Sinai, and to keep Hamas in check.   They in turn, use part of the money to buy crowd control weapons and ammunition to keep suppress any opposition.   They Egyptian people will not soon forget who bought the bullets that killed the martyrs in Tahir Square.

I understand where Professor Kupchan is coming from and I agree, for the most part, with what is written here.

Most Americans think, even today, that ours is the best model for governance. Most Americans, even today, think it is our mission - call it American exceptionalism - to bring the world over to our side. The problems are two-fold:

1. We, as a nation, are going through our own period of regression and our own democracy is in peril of changing into a theocratic oligarchy.

2. As well-meaning as we may be, we need to understand that democracy isn't something that is instituted on the tail end of a revolution's whim. Democracy is a process that has taken centuries to actually happen in Europe. It is usually bloody.

To expect Egypt, a nation that has never known democratic rule, to transition from autocratic rule to a democratically-elected and functioning government is pure fantasy. Everywhere we've installed a so-called "democratic" government, we've failed. Everywhere we've insisted on backing this or that side, we've not only failed, but made enemies. We need to stop dictating the terms of other nations' development. If democracy is in the cards, they will work towards it the same way other democratic nations have. We can't make things happen any faster or make people any readier before they actually are.

If I won $10million, I am assuming this is before taxes. Thus take off about $3.3 million right off the bat. (Not complaining, just budgeting.) I would pay off certain big debts (mortgage/student loans/etc) I would try to set up annuity or trust funds to give an annual income of whatever.

Once I had the basic needs taken care of, I would work at something I wanted to work at. Maybe it would be my own business without the pressure of having make a lot of profit. There are projects I would do that might not pay off for a while, but I wouldn't have to worry about my family going hungry or without shelter.

Work helps define us and I wouldn't want to be without purpose or having someone need me. Work helps us socialize and feel useful. Humans need that. Even if I only did volunteer work, I would need something to pass the time.

The winnings would give me some security and the opportunity to work as I wanted.

Indeed. As an American abroad, I fly to the US at least once a year. I will not cross the ocean in a US-based carrier's plane under any circumstances. The fares are usually relatively close in price, but the difference is staggering -- in customer service, efficiency, comfort, etc. (Mind you, coach class is never actually comfortable for anyone larger than a five-year-old, but there are degrees of misery and US-based carriers all apparently studied passenger comfort and well-being under the Borgias.)

We would travel more in the US for leisure, but hate US carriers so much that we'd rather spend our money on airlines which seem to take at least a little less delight in torturing their customers. (Ryanair is the obvious exception; Michael O'Leary longs for the day when he can just stack passengers like cordwood.)

When you add the TSA's ridiculous security performance art routine, it just isn't worth it.

It's a fact of modern American life that air travel today is a combination of increasingly expensive, often unpleasant, and staggeringly crowded. You don't have to be a frequent flyer to have noticed that your travel options are growing ever limited, and that, irrespective of technical compliance with whatever regulations or laws ostensibly governing the industry, it's hard not conclude that the remaining national carriers are effectively colluding to maintain, and gradually increase, ticket pricing over time. Add to that the new trends toward bait-and-switch online advertising and incessant nickle-and-diming to the gate and beyond, and it's no wonder most people would rather visit their dentist than fly.

If the end result of the consolidation of US airlines is reduced consumer choice, diminished routes, and higher prices, and if the dynamics of the business now mitigate against the prospect of new domestic airline start-ups, then maybe it's time foreign carriers were offered greater access to US markets. Travel within the EU these days is a fair cut above flying within the US on just about every level, especially price. Perhaps adding a little international flavor to the stale current US mix might make for a return to friendlier skies.

'The stodgy part --'

Just checking, Laszlo. You do know that that was just some collective leg-pulling, don't you? I'm a fan.

btw, the Taci-Laci and Túrógombóc still have not surfaced...Too obscure, perhaps.

I never skip the stodgy part, Lasz.

I have stacks of classical music cd's. I just don't know much about it beyond enjoying listening to it.

Laszlo:

When we first got the pups, we debated long and hard about what to name them.

One suggestion was ANDANTE for the male (Tito), and Allegro for the female (Coco). The kids wanted musically related names and I wanted the names to reflect their respective genders. We considered Allegra but realized it was a drug used to treat allergy sufferers, so we discarded that line of thought.

We wanted short, distinct sounding names so the dogs would recognize them even when calling them from a distance. So much for that, I don't think they really know their individual names since they both respond when either one is called.

I still think ANDANTE and Allegro are great names for dogs though.

I loved the grid with open interlocking spaces, the low number of entries, blocks and shorts. I also loved about 95% of the entries. I wasn't crazy about NEEDERS, YESM, ANILL, EME, the 13th Spanish letter and ENE, the 14th Spanish letter, but the fabulous long entries more than made up for these.

The cluing was DELICIOUS throughout: misdirecting, twisted, some of them downright evil: the ear plug, La Junta and the one for the MIROS on the wall come to mind, but there were more.

I had beehive for ANTFARM, adagios for ANDANTE, they say for SOMESAY, lion cubs instead of BEARCUBS and some air for SALTAIR, a resort in Utah.

The stodgy part -- you are welcome to skip it.

******************
The "ANDANTE favori" by Beethoven, WoO 57 (= without opus) was originally intended as the second movement of his Waldstein Sonata.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEmaEgWPphc

I selected this only because I was listening to the Waldstein earlier today and it reminded me of this beautiful piece that was left on the cutting room floor.
******************

What a terrific Saturday puzzle! Enjoy your weekend.

Dr. Nick;

We shouldn't too-easily cave to the temptation to regard these mega-industries as so similar that they're comparable. The telecom industry is perhaps our most regulated industry, and the inefficiencies imposed by that pervasive regulation have made it very difficult to grow, EXCEPT by consolidation. But the airline industry, while also heavily regulated, still determines its own prices without needing to go to states and the feds hat-in-hand, and have a lot more discretion in the level of service provided and how they provide it. They have far less excuse for not being managed in sufficiently competent ways to permit growth without predatory pricing practices.

John:

I agree, but I believe most gates actually are owned by airlines, which would require that the whole system change -- if so, it should change, because a great lever for imposing public policy would be apportionment of gates.

Rima:

I did reply to you, but it was a funny, snarky comment on MoveOn.org, and I suspect that it offended. I almost always respond to serious comments, but not all are published.

When someone very badly wants to make vice-president, there's nothing quite like a creative approach to distract from the company's poor quarterly performance by suggesting a merger, an acquisition or a divestiture to garner sufficient support to get him (or her) that bump.

But, Joe, it's not too late. Congress could mandate the breaking up of United and Delta, or a federal court could do it as a result of a Justice Dept. lawsuit just as it did in 1974, which resulted in the 1984 Bell System (AT&T) break-up. It's never too late and you're never too old to play with toys.

As a matter of fact, after the American/US Airways thumbs-down, and given our experiences with de-regulation of airlines, this would be a perfectly logical next step.

There are advantages to size other than merely "pricing power" arising from near-monopolies. But those advantages accrue primarily to the airlines, not to their customers. And there are a few more of us than there are of them.

What I'd like to see is prohibition of the big guys from flying short-hauls. They could still fly the same routes, but only when their hub-to-hub jaunts are legs in a far longer point-to-point run and they're not just selling seats for a leg. This could open the skies for smaller carriers that specialize in the short-hauls: likely would have a JetBlue effect on prices generally, particularly if gates at airports are guaranteed for the small guys.

But it's never too late to make major-airline execs' lives miserable.
Ah, Braniff!

" surly flight attendants"??  ~ In my experience, flight attendants are usually polite, pleasant and try to be helpful.  Some of them on some occasions may be aloof but to describe the entire flight attendant cohort as surly is an exaggeration.
Ah, Western - the only way to fly!

I happened to be flying a good deal between Dallas and Washington, DC in the 1980s when Braniff was still around. Every time Braniff made a move, especially on pricing, American countered it. American Airlines, also based in the Dallas-Ft.Worth area, essentially engaged in a death match battle with Braniff. We know who lost that one. There are anti-trust provisions against predatory pricing when a bigger company tries to drive a smaller one into the ground, but apparently no one bothered to consider those laws in the case of American v. Braniff (or any other airline battle, for that matter).

Safety has improved markedly, but that is probably mainly due to improved aircraft and training. Otherwise, the airlines have been trying to destroy each other, if one can apply any after the fact logic to their business which, at many points, has seemed ridiculous. There are many ways to achieve monopoly power, the goal of all business owners when possible, and running the competition out of the market entirely is one of the most effective. Bankruptcy laws have been used to that same end.

Now, if we are ever likely to have true competition again, the govt., is probably going to have to intervene in a major way to see that start-up airlines can get "slots" at major airports. Since that is very unlikely to happen, we're stuck. Poor service, surly flight attendants, high prices, prison like searches before boarding. 3 cheers for deregulation.

http://terryreport.com

Just back from two weeks in Paris. So much to do! We did most of what is mentioned with our 14 year old. We also took a day trip to Reims, which I highly recommend just to take the train and see a bit of the countryside. And it is a lovely, quaint town. And great food.

I highly recommend getting the museum pass, it was worth it. But some places still made us get a ticket, even though it was free, for our daughter, who did not need a pass. Kids get in free with a parent who has a pass.

And we stayed in Montparnasse, which is away from the tourist scene and has many fine neighborhood bistros to enjoy with locals. Also a big hit was the Monoprix in Montparnasse. It is an upscale, French version of Target. We loved going there.

And we loved how close the metro at Gare Montparnasse was. It was great.

We also loved going to the Centre Georges Pompidou. It was awesome and the views spectacular. A great place to take kids. It has wonderful art.

Grindewald,

You are exactly right. There is very strong evidence that human activities are causing climate changes. Until there is habitat collapse( crop failure and extreme drought) it is only theoretical as you say. When it does happen, options and ability to act will be severely constrained. There are examples of habitat collapse occurring at this moment and we should expect and extrapolate future occurences. To not act would be as irresponsible as the theorectical drunken driving. That has already been outlawed.

Grindelwald,

Ethics only count if there is a choice to be made. If there is no choice, then what Mark said makes a lot of sense.

Grindelwald,

There won't be proof until it happens, of course. Then it will be too late. Continuing on a course that has a very high probability of leading to disaster is not a sign of intelligence.
Since we are on our way to certain habitat collapse and species extinction, what is the game plan? Lets just say it. Everyone is on their own.  Good luck to the next generations.

Great story. I went to Italy to find the little town where my grandmother came from and was astounded to not only find the house where she was born and raised, but was also welcomed by her younger brother's son who lived down the street. I was practically speechless. I kept saying "I can't believe this is happening. This is so amazing." I was given a huge meal, and gifts for the entire family back in America. There had been no contact since my grandmother left home back around 1910.

Fortunately, I had brought a translator with me, just in case I did find anyone, but did not expect to need him. I just figured I would need a safe companion for the trip and he did the driving, which was hours away up in the hills. I would have never found it without him nor would I have been able to communicate with them.

I hired the driver/translator in the nearest big town, which was Sorrento. I went to a rental car place and asked if I could rent a car plus driver who could speak both Italian and English. I paid extra but it was definitely worth it.
Ah, Braniff!

I cheated on a computer test in my freshman year of high school with a few if my classmates. We got caught because the teacher anticipating cheating in a large lecture class passed out different versions of the test in the same rows.  He was also the philosophy teacher and he imagined a unique punishment for us that was highly effective on my part. He would not turn us in to the dean as school policy dictated but instead  had us come out to school 2 consecutive Saturdays and watch  the movie Gandhi which had just come out. All 3.5 hours of it. He then had us write a 10 page paper on the moral lessons contained therein and how they may have changed our vantage point on cheating. I never cheated again on anything. Ever. Kids shouldn't just be punished but should be made to think about the ramifications of their actions. This is not a strait forward process and sometimes requires some creativity on the part of the parents but its worth it.
Wow! I completely agree with each and every syllable! Write up a MoveOn petition and I'll sign it!

Excellent answer to this column's puzzling conclusion. The only thing I can figure is that this is an effort at "balance" because today's Times' news article is more negative about the merger. By this logic, every merger proposal that comes along now must be allowed--even if it means there is only one gigantic airline left.

Actually, it's more like closing the barn door when 3/4 of the horses have gone out, but there are still a few left. Or capping the Deep Water Horizon well after millions of barrels of oil has leaked but it is still spewing. Or banning the sale of assault weapons when millions are already in circulation.

I would expect an business columnist to have a better understanding of the principle of "sunk costs." The fact that the previous mergers cannot be undone does not negate the benefit of blocking this one, assuming that blocking this merger would be overall beneficial.

How best to manage the airline industry is not a simple problem. No passenger likes increased fares, less frequent and more crowded flights, losing leg room, paying to check bags, or paying for lousy meals that used to be free. On the other hand, despite all this supposed gouging of the consumer, most airlines are either operating on a small profit margin or at a loss. Further efforts to increase revenues and lower expenses are inevitable if the industry is to remain viable. If Al Qaeda were to bring down a jet with an antiaircraft missile we'd better brace for additional bankruptcies.

If American were forced to liquidate, would that lead to more or less competition than a merger with US Air?

KS, For this relatively innocuous comment, you amass seven reco's???
What is this strange attraction, I suspect it's mostly due to the fact you post using such an intriguingly exotic screen name?
Methinks, henceforth, I'm going to post under the pseudonym "Omar Khayyam"...that should grab 'em!
Hee Hee Hee

WHH

KS, I just learned, much to my chagrin, that my better half, LR, gave you your eighth reco of the morning!
She explained her perfidy by saying your comment was delivered entirely with tongue-in-cheek...TICMA!!!

Howie, Doth bloweth ANILL wind in Quincy!

EEN,

"Thoughtful" and "meandering" would describe my journey.

I mean, my journey to find my solve time on the NYT list of "Play Against the Clock" solvers, ranked from quickest to ... not as quick.

Does the phrase "this scroll bar really goes down that far?" mean anything?

You've got your fast solvers, your average solvers, your slow solvers, and your solvers who went and did something else while the clock was running. My solve time for this puzzle would leave doubt as to whether I fell in the last category -- and I worked the puzzle to completion without taking a break!

-- too braindead to remember my initials

My fastest time ever:  it took me just 2 minutes and 32 seconds to complete the puzzle!!!!! This time was spread over the 90 minutes or so it took me to think of the answers, take time-outs, and coach myself. But, still, only 2:32 to actually fill out the grid. Pretty good, yes?

comments.commentTitle: You can’t put genius in a Bottle.
comments.commentBody: And a fictional feature film cannot recreate the presence of a man so gifted with visions, and also possessing the ability to create a magnificent company to realize them -- over and over again. A documentary might come close.  I recall one of the filmmaker David Lean, a scene showing him in collaboration with his frequent screenwriting partner Robert Bolt.  It captured a moment when Lean, with little diplomacy but with enough icy respect to spare poor Bolt humiliation in front of the camera, rejected Bolt’s impassioned pitch to the director.  A documentary showing Jobs in a series of design meetings might have done it.  But the notion of an actor portraying Jobs - like Jobs or not - seems a conceit that would find backing only in “Hollywood."
Just remember how long it took the do-nothing Congress to make an exception from the sequestration for the FAA, so the airlines that take them home and back to Washington wouldn't be delayed.

I recently traveled by air from the US to several points in Latin America. On one of my flights on a US carrier, there were no pillows or blankets available despite the fact that we were traveling between 12AM - 5AM. Anything you wanted to drink or eat, including bottled water, or anything you wanted to watch on a screen had a price tag attached. My second two flights between two other Latin American countries were on a US partner airline, and while we were given pillows, blankets, movies, TV programs, dinner and drinks (including beer and wine), there was virtually no leg room despite one of the overnight flights being a 7 hour journey. I could barely cross my legs, and getting up and out of the seat to use the restroom was a complete hassle for me and surrounding passengers. On my return flights I paid extra for some leg room on two different flights because of their duration, but felt that I shouldn't have to do so. All travelers should be able to cross their legs, leave their seats to use restrooms, and be able to order water, soft drinks, coffee and/or tea without so much trouble. They should be able to check a suitcase, too.

Force members of Congress, CEOs of large corporations, and senior airline management to travel on these long, overpriced flights in coach for a week or two and I bet we'll see some changes.

Yeah, I'll kind of go with that. I've been flying for years on competitive routes, mainly BWI to Chicago, and the "legacy carriers" always beat Southwest by a few bucks. Plus you know where you're going to sit.

In response to this: "Even Southwest Airlines, long a low-cost airline, began raising prices."

It is my view that Southwest has abandoned its historic role as a low cost carrier. While I have not done a comprehensive study, I have often found lower fares on the legacy carriers than on Southwest.

They are very clever in the way they handle their pricing. They run several big sales long in advance of the busy vacation and tourist travel periods of the year. So, if you are planning two months ahead of time to visit grandmother's house or go on vacation, you can find a decent fare (still not necessarily lower than other fares). Everyone else who wants to travel without long advance planning is more than likely going to pay more than a legacy carrier. Plus, Southwest has added a bunch of business perks on top of their regular fares (early boarding, etc.) to try to get more business travelers. Over all, it adds up to this: Southwest isn't the lowest any more, by far.

The airline seems to be riding on its reputation of being a low cost carrier rather than being one in fact. To the minds of millions, Southwest opened up the sky to those who do not make big salaries. The budget traveler, who previously would have driven, taken a bus or stayed home, felt empowered. SW would come into a new market with low fares and people who had never flown, or very seldom flown, suddenly believed that flying was affordable. Southwest has left the low cost strategy behind.

http://terryreport.com

Glad they asked the players, rather than anyone else! Why? Nobody cares, outside of a few of us... This great athletic sport is dying, especially in the United States, except for all the hungry eastern Slavic, and a few Chinese emigres! You have the perfect storm, with many Americans too lazy to play the game, becoming more elitist than ever, with the U.S.T.A. still running the show, and have you seen the new ticket prices for this year's U.S. Open?! Perfect example of this, is listening to the U.S.T.A. say, how adding roofs to the two major venues at the Open will further expand the enjoyment for the common folks attending the Open! Only caveat being, is that the common folks can't afford to attend the Open anymore, and with the expansion, a number of the courts, the common folks, once were allowed to play on, will now be gone!! Besides, Bartoli is French, and Americans care a lot more about their fries and toast!!!

Players should not welcome cheaters in their midst - whether he plays on their team or on other teams.  A-Rod has admitted himself that he cheated and even now he has made no attempt to say he is innocent.  He simply says he is 'disappointed'.  Hogwash.  Bench him.

"We simply do not have high inflation."

How wonderful - because here in Germany the official "inflation rate" for the last year is 5.7% but it feels -(like the weather - when a cold wind is blowing) - like double that amount -(because some daily food expenses are up 30-40%)

AND one has to avoid "old folks homes" in the US because I have so many statements in front of me where - like in the case "kathynj" commented about the yearly rates went "through" the roof" - AND I one has to avoid nearly every desireable city in CAL or NY because there alone the rents are up by 10 to 15%.

" surly flight attendants"??  ~ In my experience, flight attendants are usually polite, pleasant and try to be helpful.  Some of them on some occasions may be aloof but to describe the entire flight attendant cohort as surly is an exaggeration.
